He said his party is associated with the movement and was willing to dissolve the party if the state was formed.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2010-12-26/india/28241325_1_telangana-bill-telangana-congress-leaders-kcr |title=Take party, give me state: KCR to Congress |publisher=Articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com |date=2010-12-26 |accessdate=2013-07-31}}</ref>
=== Release of the report and summary of findings === The Indian Home Ministry released the 505 page [[Srikrishna committee on Telangana|Srikrishna committee]] on 6 January 2011. The committee opined that most regions of Telangana (excluding Hyderabad) were either "on par or a shade lower" than Coastal Andhra. When Hyderabad is included, Telangana fared better. The most backward of all regions was in fact Rayalaseema. The committee, however, agreed with the violations of GO 610. Most violations, however, have been in the education and health sectors due to dearth of qualified locals. It also noted that the funds released for educational institutions in Telangana were lower than in the other two regions of the state. The committee did not see the Telangana movement as a threat to national integrity. Noting the emotions in the general public about the issue, a perceived neglect in implementation of assurances given to the region,it also said that "The continuing demand, therefore, for a separate Telangana, the Committee felt, has some merit and is not entirely unjustified". The conclusion of the report included the following statements "Therefore, after taking into account all the pros and cons, the Committee did not think it to be the most preferred, but the second best, option. Separation is recommended only in case it is unavoidable and if this decision can be reached amicably amongst all the three regions"
=== Solutions proposed === The report discusses six solutions to the problem, the preferred option being keeping the State united by simultaneously providing certain definite constitutional and statutory measures for socio-economic development and political empowerment of Telangana region through the creation of a statutorily empowered Telangana Regional Council. The second best option is bifurcation of the State into Telangana and Seemandhra as per existing boundaries, with Hyderabad as the capital of Telangana and Seemandhra to have a new capital.<ref name="Srikrishna Committee Report – Vol I">{{cite web|url=http://pib.nic.in/archieve/others/2011/jan/d2011010502.pdf |title=Srikrishna Committee Report – Vol I (Main Report) |format=PDF |accessdate=13 January 2012|pages=407, 450}} {{PD-notice}}</ref><ref>[http://pib.nic.in/archieve/others/2011/jan/d2011010503.pdf Srikrishna Committee Report – Vol II (Appendix to the report)]</ref>
=== Reactions to the report === The eighth chapter of the report was not made public for undisclosed reasons. After a judgement delivered by Justice L Narasimha Reddy of Andhra Pradesh High Court, the contents of the "secret" chapter were submitted to the High Court.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://archive.indianexpress.com/news/telangana-hc-verdict-brings-out-secret-portion-of-srikrishna-report/766634/ |title=Telangana: HC verdict brings out 'secret' portion of Srikrishna report |publisher=Indian Express |date=24 March 2011 |accessdate=4 August 2014}}</ref> The Chief Justice, in his 60 page judgement,<ref>[http://hc.ap.nic.in/orders/wp_1569_2011.html 60 page judgement] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110929171622/http://hc.ap.nic.in/orders/wp_1569_2011.html |date=29 September 2011 }}</ref> said "The Committee travelled beyond the terms of reference in its endeavour to persuade the Union of India not to accede to the demand for Telangana". The judgement also quoted the SKC report's 8th chapter and said "The manoeuvre suggested by the Committee in its secret supplementary note poses an open challenge, if not threat, to the very system of democracy." The eighth chapter was not make public after division bench comprising the Chief Justice of the AP high court has stayed the order of Justice L Narasimha Reddy.<ref>{{cite web|author=26 April 2011 DC Correspondent Hyderabad |url=http://www.deccanchronicle.com/channels/cities/hyderabad/secret-t-report-sealed-cover-157 |title=Secret T-report in sealed cover |work=Deccan Chronicle |location=India |date=26 April 2011 |accessdate=12 October 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=26 April 2011 DC Correspondent Hyderabad |url=http://www.deccanchronicle.com/channels/cities/hyderabad/hc-bench-keeps-t-report-secret-164 |title=HC bench keeps T-report secret |work=Deccan Chronicle |location=India |date=26 April 2011 |accessdate=12 October 2011}}</ref> Hence, the facts of the comments of the judge on the eighth chapter remain unverified.
== 2011 ==
=== Non-cooperation movement and Million March === {{Main|Early 2011 Telangana protests}} On 17 February 2011, a noncooperation movement was started which lasted for 16 days with participation by 3,00,000 government employees. It caused a loss of Rs 8 billion per day in revenue to government.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rediff.com/news/slide-show/slide-show-1-telangana-fury-is-costing-ap-rs-800-cr-a-day/20110224.htm |title=Telangana fury is costing AP Rs 800 cr a day |publisher=Rediff.com |date=24 February 2011 |accessdate=13 January 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.hindu.com/2011/03/04/stories/2011030455490900.htm |title=Telangana issue disrupts Parliament proceedings |work=The Hindu |location=India |date=4 March 2011 |accessdate=13 January 2012}}</ref> In February and March, Assembly session was boycotted for weeks and Parliament session was disrupted for several days by Telangana representatives.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sify.com/news/pro-telangana-mlas-to-boycott-ap-assembly-budget-session-news-national-ldcwaciifed.html |title=Pro-Telangana MLAs to boycott AP Assembly budget session |publisher=Sify.com |date=2 March 2011 |accessdate=13 January 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/states/andhra-pradesh/article1537080.ece | location=Chennai, India |work=The Hindu | title=Telangana Cong MLAs end boycott of AP House | date=14 March 2011}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.siasat.com/english/news/congress-telangana-mps-sport-black-bands-lok-sabha |title=Congress' Telangana MPs sport black bands in Lok Sabha |publisher=Siasat.com |date=4 March 2011 |accessdate=13 January 2012}}</ref>
Million March was organised by Telangana JAC in Hyderabad on 10 March 2011. Many seemandhra bound police were dropped into Hyderabad city to stop the Telangana movement. In a move to disrupt the march,seemandhra police arrested over thousand activists throughout the region and closed down entry to Hyderabad city by stopping certain transportation services and diverting traffic.<ref>{{cite web|author=10 March 2011 DC Hyderabad |url=http://www.deccanchronicle.com/hyderabad/1-lakh-arrested-across-telangana-tjac-035 |title=1 lakh arrested across Telangana: TJAC |work=The Deccan Chronicle |location=India |date=10 March 2011 |accessdate=13 January 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=10 March 2011 DC Karimnagar/Nizamabad |url=http://www.deccanchronicle.com/karimnagar/cops-block-all-roads-capital-003 |title=Cops block all roads to capital |work=The Deccan Chronicle |location=India |date=10 March 2011 |accessdate=13 January 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sify.com/news/thousands-defy-government-march-for-telangana-news-national-ldkvajffhbe.html |title=Thousands defy government, march for Telangana |publisher=Sify.com |date=10 March 2011 |accessdate=13 January 2012}}</ref> Around 50,000 people reached the venue of the march, Tank Bund by hoodwinking police.<ref>[http://www.deccanchronicle.com/hyderabad/t-men-fool-cops-wedding-350] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110311213755/http://www.deccanchronicle.com/hyderabad/t-men-fool-cops-wedding-350 |date=11 March 2011 }}</ref> Telangana activists damaged 16 statues of personalities representing Andhra culture and threw some of the remnants into the lake.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fullhyderabad.com/hyderabad-news/million-march-intensifies-in-hyderabad-statues-on-tank-bund-damaged-3823#tabs |title=Million March In Hyderabad: Statues On Tank Bund Demolished – Hyderabad News on fullhyd.com |publisher=Fullhyderabad.com |date=10 March 2011 |accessdate=13 January 2012}}</ref>
In November 2011, Telangana Rashtra Samiti Vidyarthi Vibhagam (TRSV) state president Balka Suman was arrested by Hyderabad police after cases were registered against him in connection with damaging statues on Tank Bund during the 'Million March,' attacking police personnel, damaging police and seemandhra media vehicles.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2011-11-29/hyderabad/30453669_1_ccs-police-stations-ou |work=The Times Of India |location=India | title=Telangana student wing leader arrested |date=29 November 2011}}</ref>
=== Mass resignations === {{Main|Mid 2011 Telangana protests}} From April till June, the movement saw a lull,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dayafterindia.com/detail.php?headline=content&catid=2134|title=Telangana movement set to enter crucial phase|work=dayafterindia.com|access-date=29 March 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130404210002/http://dayafterindia.com/detail.php?headline=content&catid=2134#|archive-date=4 April 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> with different parties citing various reasons and fresh deadlines to renew the agitation. In July, 81 of 119 Telangana MLAs in the state, 12 out of 15 Telangana ministers in state, 13 out of 17 Telangana MPs in Lok Sabha, 1 Rajyasabha MP (Congress), 20 MLCs resigned protesting delay in the formation of Telangana. On 20 July 30-year-old Yadi Reddy was found dead 100 yards from Parliament House in Delhi. An eight-page suicide note says the young driver from greater Hyderabad region of Telangana was upset over the government not creating a new state for his homeland. The speaker of the AP assembly on 23 July summarily rejected the resignations of all 101 MLAs citing that they were made in an emotionally surcharged atmosphere. All Telangana MPs who earlier submitted their resignations and were boycotting the parliament session also decided to attend the parliament monsoon session citing Sonia Gandhi's ill health.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2011-08-05/hyderabad/29854199_1_upa-government-telangana-congress-mps-goodwill | work=The Times Of India | title=T MPs on 'goodwill' mode | date=2011-08-05}}</ref>
=== Sakala Janula Samme === {{Main|Late 2011 Telangana protests}} On 12 September 2011, a day before Sakala Janula Samme (All people's strike), TRS organised a public meeting in Karimnagar which was attended by over a million people including [[TJAC]] leaders, BJP and New Democracy party leaders.<ref name="KCR on 9 October">{{cite web|title=Telangana is angry and will erupt in flames: KCR|url=http://www.rediff.com/news/report/telangana-is-angry-and-will-erupt-in-flames-kcr/20110912.htm|publisher=Rediff.com|accessdate=9 October 2011}}</ref>
Starting 13 September, as part of 'strike by all section of people' supporting Telangana statehood, government employees throughout Telangana stayed out of work, lawyers boycotted courts<ref>{{cite web|title=Telangana: Administrative work affected|url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/telangana-administrative-work-affected/183823-60-114.html|publisher=IBNLive.com India|accessdate=9 October 2011}}</ref> and 60,000 coal miners of Singareni Collieries (SCCL Ltd.) also joined the strike.<ref>{{cite web|title=Strike at Singareni Collieries may hit power production|url=http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/industry-and-economy/article2450632.ece|publisher=The Hindu Business Line|accessdate=9 October 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Telangana collieries strike hits power supplies in south India|url=http://www.daijiworld.com/news/news_disp.asp?n_id=115879|publisher=Daijiworld Media Pvt Ltd|accessdate=9 October 2011}}</ref> Soon government teachers, state road transport corporation employees and state electricity board employees joined the strike.<ref>{{cite news|title=Govt teachers join hands for Telangana|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2011-09-17/hyderabad/30168912_1_telangana-region-swamy-goud-telangana-protagonists|work=The Times of India |location=India|accessdate=9 October 2011|date=17 September 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Transport employees' strike paralyse Telangana|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2011-09-19/hyderabad/30175479_1_rtc-management-rtc-strike-separate-telangana-state|work=The Times of India |location=India|accessdate=9 October 2011|date=19 September 2011}} {{dead link|date=June 2012|bot=RjwilmsiBot}}</ref>
On a call given by JAC, road blockades on national highways throughout Telangana, rail blockade and the strike of [[auto rikshaw]] union were organised on 24 and 25 September causing disruption in transport services.<ref>{{cite news|title=Telangana activists block highway|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/states/andhra-pradesh/article2467382.ece|work=The Hindu |accessdate=9 October 2011|location=Chennai, India|first=S. Harpal|last=Singh|date=19 September 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Statehood protests paralyse transport in Telangana|url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2011-09-25/news/30200846_1_rail-blockade-services-or-local-trains-telangana-joint-action-committee|work=The Times of India |location=India|accessdate=9 October 2011|date=25 September 2011}} {{dead link|date=June 2012|bot=RjwilmsiBot}}</ref> Virtually all sections of people joined this strike.<ref>{{cite web|title=People power driving Telangana agitation |url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/people-power-fuels-agitation-for-telangana/1/153130.html|publisher=India Today|accessdate=9 October 2011}}</ref> On 30 September, as the strike entered the 18th day, even while Congress central leadership met several Telangana congress leaders, JAC called a bundh in Hyderabad city.<ref>{{cite web|title=Telangana crisis: Bandh in Hyderabad, talks in Delhi|url=http://www.ndtv.com/article/india/telangana-crisis-bandh-in-hyderabad-talks-in-delhi-137452|publisher=NDTV|accessdate=9 October 2011}}</ref> On 2 October, JAC leaders, employee unions leaders and TRS leaders including KCR met Prime minister to explain the situation in Telangna due to the strike and asked to expedite the decision on the statehood demand.<ref>{{cite web|title=Telangana issue: PM steps in, meets KCR and says working on solution|url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/telangana-issue-pm-steps-in-meets-kcr-and-says-working-on-solution/855001/|publisher=The Indian Express Limited|accessdate=9 October 2011}}</ref> The strike has resulted in an unprecedented power crisis in the state with only 223 MU of power generated against the demand of 275MU impacting both the industry and agriculture.<ref>{{cite news|title=Telangana stir, energy crisis could hit economy of Andhra Pradesh|url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2011-10-05/news/30246969_1_coal-production-ntpc-s-ramagundam-heavy-power-cuts|work=The Times of India |location=India|accessdate=9 October 2011|date=5 October 2011}}</ref>
Due to Rail blockade call on 15 October 110 trains were cancelled and 68 trains were diverted by authorities. The railways operated 12 trains and Hyderabad metro trains with full police protection. Telangana protestors tried to have sit in on rail platforms or on railway tracks at various places. Police arrested thousands of protesters including 8 MPs and 4 MLAs.<ref>{{cite web|title=Telangana rail roko: 8 MPs, 4 MLAs among several arrested|url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/telangana-rail-roko-8-mps-4-mlas-among-several-arrested/860273/|publisher=Indian Express 15 October 2011|accessdate=17 October 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Railway station turns battleground|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2011-10-17/hyderabad/30289463_1_railway-station-rail-roko-protesters|publisher=Indian Express 17 October 2011|accessdate=17 October 2011|date=17 October 2011}}</ref> On 16 October public transport employees called off the strike. Within days other unions too called off the strike one after another. After 42 days, on 24 October, remaining employees unions called off the strike. [[M. Kodandaram]] said that the strike had impacted the overall thinking of the Centre towards creation of separate State and the movement will continue with other protest activities.<ref>{{cite web|title=42-day Telangana strike ends|url=http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/industry-and-economy/government-and-policy/article2568330.ece|publisher=Business Line|accessdate=31 October 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111026191103/http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/industry-and-economy/government-and-policy/article2568330.ece|archivedate=26 October 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
On 29 October 2011, three Congress party MLAs belonging to Telangana region resigned and joined TRS in protest as they were disappointed with Congress leadership's delay in Telangana state formation.<ref>{{cite web|title=Three AP Congress MLAs quit over Telangana issue, join TRS|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/telangana-congress-mlas-join-trs/1/158004.html|publisher=India Today|accessdate=31 October 2011}}</ref>
On 1 November, Congress MLA Komatireddy Venkat Reddy started an indefinite hunger strike until the central government announced a roadmap for Telangana state.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2011-11-02/hyderabad/30349650_1_telangana-ministers-komatireddy-venkat-reddy-telangana-congress-mps |work=The Times Of India |location=India | title=T ministers main hurdle |date=2 November 2011}}</ref> 5 days later, the fast was broken when police arrested him under Section 309 of IPC (attempt to commit suicide) and shifted him to NIMS, Hyderabad where he was kept under intravenous fluids. He ended his fast on 9 November.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/india/report_telangana-congress-mla-breaks-eight-day-old-fast_1609984 |title=Telangana: Congress MLA breaks eight-day-old fast – India – DNA |publisher=Dnaindia.com |date=9 November 2011 |accessdate=13 January 2012}}</ref> 97-year-old Freedom fighter Konda Laxman Bapuji also launched his week-long satyagraha at Jantar Mantar in New Delhi, demanding statehood to the region.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/telangana-congress-leaders-protests-konda-lakshman-bapuji/1/158270.html |title=Pro-statehood Congress leaders rekindle Telangana fire, 97-year-old joins stir : Telangana Proponents News – India Today |publisher=Indiatoday.intoday.in |date=2 November 2011 |accessdate=13 January 2012}}</ref>
== 2012 == {{Main|2012 Telangana protests}} In January, BJP led by State party president Kishan Reddy started the 22-day Telangana 'Poru Yatra', across 88 assembly constituencies stressing the need for Telangana state.<ref>{{cite web|title=Gadkari flags off BJP’s Telangana Yatra|url=http://www.deccanherald.com/content/220508/gadkari-flags-off-bjps-telangana.html|publisher=Deccan Helard, 19 Jan 2012|accessdate=30 January 2012}}</ref> Though the tour was successful in reiterating the party's pro-Telangana stance, it could not garner as much support as hoped because of the indifferent attitude of the TRS and TJAC. In fact the failure of the TRS in declaring its support to Kishan Reddy’s yatra has resulted in growing differences between the two parties.<ref>[http://dailypioneer.com/nation/42239-only-bjp-can-fulfill-the-dream-of-telangana.html ‘Only BJP can fulfill the dream of Telangana’]</ref>
By-elections took place on 18 March in 6 Telangana assembly seats. TRS won four out of five seats it contested with huge majorities ranging from 15,024 to 44,465. In two out of the four seats won by TRS (Kamareddy and Adilabad), the TRS candidates polled less number of votes compared to 2009 assembly elections when they contested as candidates from TDP which was in alliance with TRS.<ref>[http://www.assemblyelections.com/north-telangana-assembly-elections/nizamabad-district/kamareddy-assembly/ Kamareddy Assembly | Assembly Elections]</ref><ref>[http://www.assemblyelections.com/north-telangana-assembly-elections/adilabad-district/adilabad-assembly/ Adilabad Assembly | Assembly Elections]</ref> Ex-TDP MLA Nagam Janardhan Reddy won from Nagarkurnool seat as an independent with TJAC support. Congress lost [[Deposit (politics)#India|deposit]] in one constituency and TDP in 3 constituencies.<ref>[http://www.dailypioneer.com/home/online-channel/360-todays-newspaper/51654-telangana-fury-singes-congress-in-andhra-.html Telangana fury singes Congress in Andhra]</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ndtv.com/article/india/in-andhra-pradesh-by-polls-pro-telangana-trs-wins-four-out-of-seven-seats-188284|title=In Andhra Pradesh by-polls, pro-Telangana TRS scores big|work=NDTV.com}}</ref>
Bye-polls were conducted for 18 Assembly seats and 1 Parliament seat on 12 June. The YSRCP won 15 assembly seats and the lone Parliament seat in Seema-Andhra region. TRS's candidate managed to win the Parkal seat with a slender majority of 1562 votes over YSRCP candidate Konda Surekha. TDP finished third after polling 30,000 votes and retained its deposit. Both BJP and Congress lost their deposits.<ref>{{cite web|title=TRS ‘car’ hit by ‘auto’, again|url=http://www.deccanchronicle.com/channels/cities/hyderabad/trs-%E2%80%98car%E2%80%99-hit-%E2%80%98auto%E2%80%99-again-353|publisher=Deccan Chronicle}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Parkal warning forces Telangana Rashtra Samithi to stir up T again|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2012-06-18/hyderabad/32298084_1_telangana-sentiment-seemandhra-telangana-rashtra-samithi|publisher=Times of India|accessdate=19 June 2012|date=18 June 2012}}</ref>
In September 2012, [[Sushilkumar Shinde]], the newly appointed Home minister of India commented that the Telangana demand needs to be handled carefully since similarly carved smaller states saw increased Naxal problems.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/naxal-fear-stalling-telangana-shinde/290529-62-127.html |title=Naxalite fear stalling Telangana state, claims Shinde |publisher=Ibnlive.in.com |date= |accessdate=2013-07-31}}</ref> Addressing a public meeting in Nizamabad district, [[AIMIM]] president Asaduddin Owaisi said that formation of a separate Telangana state is not possible and reaffirmed his party's stand on the issue. He also said that Muslims would not accept a separate state.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2012-09-14/hyderabad/33843190_1_telangana-bodhan-town-separate-t-state |title=Separate T-state not possible: Asad |publisher=Articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com |date=2012-09-14 |accessdate=2013-07-31}}</ref>
On 14 August 2012, KCR gave a deadline to the centre to declare statehood in 2 weeks and promised to launch another round of agitation if the centre doesn't.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://newindianexpress.com/states/andhra_pradesh/article589707.ece|title=Decide in 14 days: KCR to Centre|work=The New Indian Express}}</ref> He later declared that he got feelers that a positive announcement will be made by Eid.<ref>{{cite web|author=T S Sudhir |url=http://www.firstpost.com/politics/with-delhi-silent-telangana-parties-to-get-into-agitation-mode-423590.html |title=With Delhi silent, Telangana parties to get into agitation mode |publisher=Firstpost |date= |accessdate=2013-07-31}}</ref> In another interview after Eid, he remarked that Sonia Gandhi has always been in favour of Telangana and that the central government will call his party for discussions in "few weeks or so"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2012-08-27/news/33425300_1_telangana-state-telangana-rashtra-samithi-telangana-region|title=Got positive signals from UPA for Telangana state but readying contingency strategy: KC Rao, TRS|work=The Economic Times}}</ref> On 6 September, KCR left for Delhi and announced that the issue will be resolved by end of September.<ref>http://www.deccanchronicle.com/channels/cities/hyderabad/centre%E2%80%99s-t-word-sept-30-kcr-877</ref> After his 23-day stay in Delhi, KCR returned to Hyderabad hoping for a final round of talks with the Congress leadership on the issue. He claimed that his discussions with several leaders was fruitful.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/telangana-trs-wants-more-talks-with-congress/297822-62-127.html |title=Telangana: TRS wants more talks with Congress |publisher=Ibnlive.in.com |date=2012-10-04 |accessdate=2013-07-31}}</ref>
=== Telangana March === After setting 30 September as the deadline for the Centre to announce the formation of Telangana, the TJAC threatened to organise a 'Telangana March' in Hyderabad on the lines of the '[[Dandi March]]' .<ref>{{cite web|title=Telangana Political Joint Action Committee plans 'Dandi March' like agitation for Telangana|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2012-09-13/hyderabad/33815944_1_chalo-hyderabad-m-kodandaram-political-joint-action-committee|publisher=Times of India|accessdate=18 September 2012}}</ref><ref name="atimes.com">Francesco Brunello Zanitti {{cite web|title=Telangana issue sparks more turmoil|url=http://www.atimes.com/atimes/South_Asia/NJ19Df02.html|publisher=Asia Times Online|date= 19 October 2012}}</ref> Anticipating violence and possibility of attack on properties of Andhraites,<ref name="zeenews.india.com">{{cite web|url=http://zeenews.india.com/news/andhra-pradesh/telangana-march-police-warn-of-action_801946.html |title=Telangana march: Police warn of action |publisher=Zeenews.india.com |date=2012-09-26 |accessdate=2013-07-31}}</ref> Police initially refused permission to the march which is scheduled around the time of [[Ganesh Chaturthi#Celebration, rituals and tradition|Ganesh Nimmajjan]] on 29 September and [[Convention on Biological Diversity#2012 COP 11|UN conference on Bio diversity]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Un Convention on Bio Diversity|url=http://www.cbdcop11india.in/home.html|accessdate=27 September 2012}}</ref> on 1 October.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/India-news/AndhraPradesh/Telangana-groups-insist-on-march-govt-says-no/Article1-936864.aspx |title=Andhra police say no to Telangana march, to act tough |publisher=Hindustan Times |date=2012-09-28 |accessdate=2013-07-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121031093704/http://www.hindustantimes.com/India-news/AndhraPradesh/Telangana-groups-insist-on-march-govt-says-no/Article1-936864.aspx |archivedate=31 October 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The Police begun checking buses and trains entering the city and students who are trying to enter the city to participate in the protest are being sent back.<ref>{{cite web|title=Telangana Million March banned by government will take place, vow activists|url=http://www.ndtv.com/article/south/telangana-million-march-banned-by-government-will-take-place-vow-activists-272995|accessdate=27 September 2012}}</ref> They identified troublemakers<ref name="zeenews.india.com" /> and arrested certain pro-Telangana activists throughout the Telangana region. Police said that there are intelligence reports that the protestors could attack properties of people of Seemandhra.<ref>{{cite web|title=Telangana groups, government heading for confrontation over march|url=http://twocircles.net/2012sep27/telangana_groups_government_heading_confrontation_over_march.html|accessdate=27 September 2012}}</ref>
On 28 September, after long discussions between JAC leaders and ministers from Telangana region, the state government ignoring warnings about the possible breakdown of law and order, gave permission for the march. The JAC leaders gave written assurance to the government that the agitation programme would be conducted in a peaceful and "gandhian" manner from 15:00 to 19:00 on 30 September on the Necklace Road on the edge of Hussain Sager lake.<ref>{{cite web|title=Government blinks, allows Telangana march|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2012-09-29/hyderabad/34163281_1_telangana-march-telangana-ministers-chalo-hyderabad-march|publisher=Times of India|accessdate=1 October 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ndtv.com/article/cities/andhra-pradesh-government-gives-permission-for-telangana-million-march-273491 |title=Andhra Pradesh government gives permission for Telangana Million March |publisher=NDTV.com |date=2012-09-29 |accessdate=2013-07-31}}</ref> [[Indian Railways]] cancelled several express and passenger trains and all local and sub-urban train services in Hyderabad reportedly on the advice of police.<ref>{{cite web|title=Telangana march: Over 40 trains to Hyderabad cancelle|url=http://www.firstpost.com/politics/telangana-march-over-40-trains-to-hyderabad-cancelled-473723.html|publisher=First post|accessdate=1 October 2012}}</ref>
On 30 September, the day of the march, Police closed the gates and blocked students at the [[Osmania University]] gate and other protestors at several places in the city when they were proceeding in rallies towards the March venue. Congress MPs from Telangana were arrested in front of Chief minister's office when they staged a dharna as they were not allowed to meet him over the detention of their party supporters who were stopped from reaching the venue.<ref>{{cite web|title=Violence mars 'Telangana March' in Hyderabad|url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/violence-mars-telangana-march-in-hyderabad/1009994/0|publisher=Indian Express|accessdate=1 October 2012}}</ref>
Though police sealed all the entry points to the Necklace Road and opened only the Buddha Bhavan route, by 4pm around 2 lakh protestors including various party leaders and their supporters reached the venue from all routes. Coming under attack from both sides, the police ceded the entire Necklace Road to the protesters who marched on till Jal Vihar. According to the Police, the protesters torched two police vehicles at People's Plaza on the Necklace Road.<ref name="hindustantimes.com">{{cite web |url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/India-news/Hyderabad/Violence-around-protest-venue-as-Telangana-march-begins/Article1-937866.aspx |title=Pro-Telangana activists defy prohibitory orders in Hyderabad |publisher=Hindustan Times |date=2012-09-30 |accessdate=2013-07-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121102163114/http://www.hindustantimes.com/India-news/Hyderabad/Violence-around-protest-venue-as-Telangana-march-begins/Article1-937866.aspx |archivedate=2 November 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The mobs also set afire three police vehicles, a couple of media outdoor broadcasting vans, machinery and a temporary cabin room of a construction company.<ref name="ibnlive.in.com">{{cite web|url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/surge-of-telangana-wave/296751-60-114.html |title=Surge of Telangana wave |publisher=Ibnlive.in.com |date=2012-10-01 |accessdate=2013-07-31}}</ref> The protesters made an attempt to set on fire a local train at Khairatabad station.<ref name="punemirror.in">{{cite web |url=http://www.punemirror.in/article/4/20121001201210010806322829dfe191f/2-lakh-march-for-Telangana-amid-clashes-in-Hyderabad.html |title=2 lakh march for Telangana amid clashes in Hyderabad, News |publisher=Punemirror.in |date=2012-10-01 |accessdate=2013-07-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121127081445/http://www.punemirror.in/article/4/20121001201210010806322829dfe191f/2-lakh-march-for-Telangana-amid-clashes-in-Hyderabad.html |archivedate=27 November 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> At the railway’s Hussainsagar junction cabin, around 1,000 Telangana supporters went on a rampage overpowering over 100 uniformed men stationed in the area and burnt down the cabin after manhandling railway staff. The entire signalling system was damaged and officials pegged the loss at around Rs. 60 lakh.<ref name="asianage.com">http://www.asianage.com/india/string-cases-telangana-march-leaders-859 {{dead link|date=July 2013}}</ref>
After 19:00, TJAC leaders violated the deadline and refused to leave the venue till the government issues a statement on Telangana.<ref>{{cite web|title=Telangana march leaves government red-faced|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/states/andhra-pradesh/telangana-march-leaves-government-redfaced/article3952161.ece|publisher=The Hindu|accessdate=2 October 2012}}</ref> Police first used water cannons and later lobbed tear gas shells on the crowd and on to the stage to force the protestors to leave the venue.<ref>{{cite web|title=Leaders of Telangana march ask protesters to stay put at venue|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2012-09-30/hyderabad/34176806_1_telangana-supporters-telangana-joint-action-committee-telangana-demand|publisher=Times of India|accessdate=2 October 2012}}</ref> Finally at midnight the JAC called off the March citing heavy rain and injured supporters.<ref>{{cite web|title=Telangana March: Protestors play dodge as cops cut off access to Hyderabad|url=http://newindianexpress.com/cities/hyderabad/article1281012.ece|publisher=New Indian Express|accessdate=2 October 2012}}</ref>
The next day, local police registered 15 cases against Kodandaram and others for conducting the march beyond the permitted time of 7 pm and till midnight and also for violence during the march. Railway police also registered cases against unidentified persons for damage to the signalling system at Lakdikapul. Cases were booked against the student leaders of TSJAC, OUJAC, Telangana Vidyarti Parishad and TVV.<ref name="asianage.com" /> The bandh drew little response in Hyderabad and was partial in Telangana districts. [[Osmania University]] students again resorted to stone throwing and police retaliated by using tear gas shells.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2012-10-01/news/34198113_1_telangana-bandh-pro-telangana-partial-response |title=Little response to Telangana bandh; students-police clash at Osmania University |publisher=Articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com |date=2012-10-01 |accessdate=2013-07-31}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/bandh-partial-in-telangana-districts/297082-60-114.html |title=Bandh partial in Telangana districts |publisher=Ibnlive.in.com |date=2012-10-02 |accessdate=2013-07-31}}</ref>
On 27 December 2012 a meeting was organised by Home minister of India to discuss the Telangana issue. It was attended by 8 political parties having significant presence in the state legislature. After hearing views of all the parties, the home minister said that this will be the last such meeting on this issue and that the government will come up with a decision within 30 days. In the meeting, MIM and CPI (M) reiterated their strong opposition to division of the state. YSR Congress remained neutral and requested the central government to take a decision. Congress representatives gave conflicting views, one supporting the division and one opposing it.<ref>{{cite web|title=Final call on Telangana in a month: Shinde|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/India-news/NewDelhi/Final-call-on-Telangana-in-a-month-Shinde/Article1-982153.aspx|publisher=Hindustan Times|accessdate=2 January 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140105044100/http://www.hindustantimes.com/India-news/NewDelhi/Final-call-on-Telangana-in-a-month-Shinde/Article1-982153.aspx|archivedate=5 January 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Centre promises Telangana decision in 30 days; Will Cong finally shed ambivalence?|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2012-12-29/india/36050580_1_statehood-sentiment-telangana-separate-state|publisher=Times of India|accessdate=2 January 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.outlookindia.com/items.aspx?artid=785105 |title=Andhra Parties Want Early Decision on Telangana |publisher=news.outlookindia.com |date= |accessdate=2013-07-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131231002303/http://news.outlookindia.com/items.aspx?artid=785105 |archivedate=31 December 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> TDP representatives gave a letter signed by its president which said that it never withdrawn its letter to Pranab Mukharjee in 2008 supporting Telangana state formation.<ref>{{cite web|title=TDP letter to Shinde|url=http://www.telugudesam.org/tdpcms/press/december2012/281212/Letter_to_Sushil_Kumar%20shinde.jpg|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130314022217/http://telugudesam.org/tdpcms/press/december2012/281212/Letter_to_Sushil_Kumar%20shinde.jpg|dead-url=yes|archive-date=14 March 2013|publisher=Telugu Desam Party|accessdate=2 January 2013}}</ref> Telangana JAC demanded more clarity from Telugu Desam before they allow TDP to be a member of JAC.<ref>{{cite web|title=TRS disposes proposal: no entry for TDP into T-JAC|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2012-12-31/hyderabad/36078833_1_jac-m-kodandaram-pro-telangana|publisher=Times of India|accessdate=2 January 2013}}</ref>
== 2013 == 2013 witnessed more protest by the TJAC including blockade of the road blockade of [[National Highway 7 (India)|NH 7]] in Mahbubnagar district. Public property was destroyed.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sadak Bandh: 8 T-leaders sent to jail|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2013-03-22/hyderabad/37935790_1_hyderabad-bangalore-highway-sadak-bandh-sadakbandh|publisher=Times if India|accessdate=30 April 2013}}</ref> This year also witnessed protest by 5 Congress MPs for 48 hours at the entrance of the Indian Parliament.<ref>{{cite web|title=‘T’ sentiment echoes in Delhi|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/andhra-pradesh/t-sentiment-echoes-in-delhi/article4669465.ece|publisher=The Hindu|accessdate=30 April 2013}}</ref>
Leaders from various political parties joined TRS in support of the movement.<ref>{{cite web|title=Senior TDP leader Kadiyam Srihari quits party|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2013-05-11/india/39186228_1_party-chief-chandrababu-naidu-tdp-telangana-statehood-issue|publisher=Times of India|accessdate=16 May 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=2 MPs, Keshava Rao join Telangana Rashtra Samithi|url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/politics/2-mps-keshava-rao-join-telangana-rashtra-samithi-113060200534_1.html|work=Wednesday, June 5, 2013 {{!}} 04:40 AM IST|publisher=Business Standard|accessdate=4 June 2013}}</ref>
=== Chalo Assembly === In May 2013, the TJAC gave a call to lay siege to the state legislative Assembly in Hyderabad on 14 June 2013 to demand the formation of Telangana. Government refused permission to the march as they had information that anti-social elements might participate in the event and cause violence like in previous events of [[2012 Telangana protests#Telangana March|''Sagara Haram'']] and [[Early 2011 Telangana protests#Million March 2011|''Million March'']] where violence erupted despite promises made by the TJAC. Police made pre-emptive arrests of activists through the region which led to stalling of the assembly proceedings by opposition parties.<ref>{{cite web|title=Andhra assembly remains paralysed over Telangana issue|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/india/1847670/report-andhra-assembly-remains-paralysed-over-telangana-issue|publisher=DNA|accessdate=13 June 2013}}</ref> The chief minister directed the Director-General of Police at a high-level review meeting not to use even rubber bullets in their efforts and observe utmost restraint in maintaining law and order. Amid fear of violence by [[Naxalite]]s after an open letter claimed to have been written by them on the rally,<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2013-06-13/hyderabad/39951242_1_sagara-haram-trs-mlas-chalo-assembly |title=Chalo assembly: Govt, Telangana Political JAC set for a joust |publisher=Articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com |date=2013-06-13 |accessdate=2013-07-31}}</ref> police sounded a high alert across the state and almost sealed all the arterial roads leading to the Assembly. Over 25,000 policemen belonging to both central and state security forces were deployed. The TJAC leaders alleged that the government has been using repressive measures to prevent them from representing the aspirations of Telangana people in a peaceful manner.<ref>{{cite web|title=Tension mounts as State goes all out to thwart ‘Chalo Assembly’ march|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/Hyderabad/tension-mounts-as-state-goes-all-out-to-thwart-chalo-assembly-march/article4811465.ece|publisher=The Hindu|accessdate=13 June 2013}}</ref> Educational institutions declared a holiday and public transport went off the roads and shops and establishments shut as a precautionary measure.<ref>{{cite web|title=Government waves an iron fist to thwart ‘Chalo Assembly’|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/Hyderabad/government-waves-an-iron-fist-to-thwart-chalo-assembly/article4811471.ece|publisher=The Hindu|accessdate=14 June 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Hyderabad under siege; shutdown today|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2013-06-14/hyderabad/39975514_1_m-kodandaram-telangana-political-jac-tjac|publisher=Times of India|accessdate=14 June 2013}}</ref>
On the day of the event in spite of the restrictions placed, police could not totally prevent Telangana activists from sneaking into prime locations and making a vain bid to rush towards the Assembly.<ref>{{cite web|title=Telangana agitation returns to centre stage|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/Hyderabad/tagitation-returns-to-centre-stage/article4813768.ece|publisher=The Hindu|accessdate=14 June 2013}}</ref> Hundreds of people including state legislators, the JAC Chairman and other leaders were arrested across the city. Osmania University campus witnessed pitched battles as police closed the campus gate to stop students leaving campus in a rally then resorted to tear gas shelling when student started stone pelting. After the march, the TJAC Chairman remarked that their goal to reach the Assembly complex and highlight their demand was fulfilled.<ref>{{cite web|title=Iron fist on Telangana protesters, bandh called today|url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/iron-fist-on-telangana-protesters-bandh-called-today/1129420/|publisher=Indian Express|accessdate=14 June 2013}}</ref>
=== Congress Core Committee Meeting ===
According to an internal survey reportedly done for the state government (cited by media sources in June), the Congress party will get around 35-40 seats out of 294 MLA seats in the state, with TRS ahead in Telangana region while YSRCP in the Seema-Andhra region. This survey was reportedly being considered to arrive at a decision on the statehood issue.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://newindianexpress.com/states/andhra_pradesh/Congress-Telangana-options-Pack-up-patch-up-or-break-up/2013/06/28/article1656658.ece |title=Congress' Telangana options: Pack up, patch up or break up |publisher=The New Indian Express |date= |accessdate=2013-07-31}}</ref>
On 30 June, Congress leaders belonging to Telangana region organised a public meeting in Hyderabad with a turn out of over 100,000 to show their support to Telangana state. It was attended by [[Damodar Raja Narasimha]], Deputy Chief minister of the state, central ministers, state ministers, MPs and MLAs who expressed the confidence that their party leadership will create the separate state soon and said that Congress will perform well in the next elections in such a situation.<ref>{{cite web|title=Telangana anytime now, say Congress leaders|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/andhra-pradesh/telangana-anytime-now-say-congress-leaders/article4866883.ece|publisher=The Hindu|accessdate=1 July 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Cong Leaders Demand Formation of Telangana|url=http://news.outlookindia.com/items.aspx?artid=802376|publisher=Outlook|accessdate=1 July 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Congress too manages huge Telangana rally in Hyderabad|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/hyderabad/Congress-too-manages-huge-Telangana-rally-in-Hyderabad/articleshow/20850511.cms|publisher=Times of India|accessdate=1 July 2013}}</ref>
On 1 July, Congress party's in-charge of the state, [[Digvijaya Singh (politician)|Digvijay Singh]] said that party is at the final stages of taking decision on Telangana issue. He also directed state chief minister, deputy chief minister and state party president (they represent assembly constituencies in [[Rayalaseema]], Telangana and [[Coastal Andhra]] regions respectively) to furnish a roadmap, keeping both options open, that could help lead to a decision.<ref>{{cite web|title=Decision on Telangana issue is final stage: Digvijaya|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2013-07-01/india/40306607_1_telangana-issue-digvijaya-singh-final-stage|publisher=Times of India|accessdate=7 July 2013}}</ref> On 11 July the three leaders presented their views in the Congress core committee meeting, post which it was announced that a decision will be taken by the [[Congress Working Committee]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Crucial meet on Telangana today|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/andhra-pradesh/crucial-meet-on-telangana-today/article4905359.ece|publisher=The Hindu|accessdate=12 July 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.deccanchronicle.com/130712/news-current-affairs/article/congress-core-committee-meet-ends-telangana-issue-referred |title=Congress Core Committee meet ends, Telangana issue referred to Congress Working Committee |publisher=Deccan Chronicle |date=2009-12-09 |accessdate=2013-07-31}}</ref>
The Chief Minister N Kiran Kumar Reddy met several MPs, MLAs and MLCs on 29 July in a bid to resolve the issue being taken up by the central Congress government.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Strife-in-Congress-over-Telangana-Andhra-leaders-meet-CM-Kiran-Reddy/articleshow/21458501.cms |title=Strife in Congress over Telangana, Andhra leaders meet CM Kiran Reddy |publisher=Timesofindia.indiatimes.com |date= |accessdate=2013-07-31}}</ref>
=== CWC resolution on bifurcation === {{See also|Samaikyandhra_Movement#Public_Protests_Aftermath|label 1=Samaikyandhra Protests due to the decision}} The Congress Working Committee (CWC) unanimously passed a resolution On 30 July to create the State of Telangana.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://zeenews.india.com/news/nation/congress-gives-nod-telangana-set-to-be-a-separate-state_865388.html|title=Congress gives nod to Telangana; Hyderabad to be joint capital|work=Zee News}}</ref> The committee also assured that the concerns of people from the remaining regions regarding sharing of water and power resources will be addressed. The bifurcation decision sparked off fresh [[Samaikyandhra Movement#Public Protests Aftermath|protests]] as part of the [[Samaikyandhra Movement]].
==== Reactions ====
TRS welcomed the decision and its chief K. Chadrashekhar Rao said that his party is fine with Hyderabad being the joint capital.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/hyderabad-joint-capital-as-ap-to-be-split-into-telangana-seemandhra/410704-62-127.html|title=Hyderabad joint capital as AP to be split into Telangana, Seemandhra|work=IBNLive}}</ref> This was seen as an attempt by the INC to merge TRS into itself for the general and provincial election after being marginalised in the Rayalseema and coastal regions by the [[YSR Congress]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rediff.com/news/slide-show/slide-show-1-telangana-demand-met-congress-eyes-merger-with-trs/20130731.htm|title=Telangana demand met, Congress eyes merger with TRS|date=31 July 2013|work=Rediff}}</ref> {{cite web|url=http://news.in.msn.com/national/bjp-to-monitor-carefully-upa%e2%80%99s-intention-on-telangana|title=News|work=msn.com}}</ref> and that their party supports the creation of Telangana and Vidarbha. They demanded that other requests for the creation of new states such as those of Gorkhaland and [[Bodoland]] need to be done by appointing a Second States Reorganisation Commission earlier too. We now demand that the government should set it up and seek a report within a specific timeframe.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.financialexpress.com/news/telangana-now-set-up-commission-for-other-states-says-bjp/1148814|title=Telangana: Now set up commission for other states, says BJP|author=Express news service|work=The Financial Express}}</ref>
Many parties and politicians including the Chief Minister-who hails from Rayalaseema- protested the bill. Some even termed it as "undemocratic". The congress and YSRCP were wiped out in the following elections, however in all three regions of the erstwhile Andhra Pradesh. [[Indian general election, 2014]].<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite web|url=http://www.ndtv.com/article/cheat-sheet/telangana-announcement-andhra-pradesh-chief-minister-kiran-kumar-reddy-leaves-for-delhi-398746 |title=Telangana announcement: Andhra Pradesh Chief Minister Kiran Kumar Reddy leaves for Delhi |publisher=NDTV.com |date= |accessdate=2013-07-31}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/ysr-congress-terms-telangana-decision-undemocratic-threatens-protest/1/297161.html |title=YSR Congress terms Telangana decision undemocratic, threatens protest |publisher=Indiatoday.intoday.in |date= |accessdate=2013-07-31}}</ref>
The decision sparked protests by the [[Gorkha Janmukti Morcha]] (GJM) in the form of an indefinite strike for [[Gorkhaland]]. GJM President [[Bimal Gurung]] also resigned from the [[Gorkhaland Territorial Administration]] in demand for Gorkhaland, citing West Bengal government's interference with its autonomy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://in.news.yahoo.com/telangana-gjm-ratchets-gorkhaland-demand-174805877.html?.tsrc=inucbr |title=After Telangana, GJM ratchets up Gorkhaland demand |publisher=In.news.yahoo.com |date= |accessdate=2013-07-31}}</ref> It was even speculated by the media that more such moves could gain steam, such as that by the [[Bundelkhand Mukti Morcha]] for [[Bundelkhand]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2013-07-13/india/40553694_1_statehood-demand-gorkha-territorial-administration-separate-state |title=Telangana could spur more statehood demands |publisher=Articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com |date=2013-07-13 |accessdate=2013-07-31}}</ref> Meanwhile, the national Home Ministry opined that the lack of development in the proposed areas and the proximity to other hotbeds in Chattishgarh's Bastar and Maharashtra's Gadhidoli regions might cause an increase in Naxalism in Telangana [[Communist Party of India (Maoist)]] if the administration is not quickly consolidated.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/telangana-may-witness-spurt-in-naxalism-home-ministry/410696-62-127.html |title=Telangana may witness spurt in Naxalism: Home Ministry |publisher=Ibnlive.in.com |date= |accessdate=2013-07-31}}</ref>
The next steps towards the re-formation of Telangana, expected by early 2014, are: The national cabinet sharing its plans with the President of India and the Andhra Pradesh legislature. The Prime Minister would then organise a committee to negotiate a consensus between the leaders from the three regions for issues such as sharing revenue and water. Both national houses of parliament would then have to pass a resolution to create Telangana.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ndtv.com/article/cheat-sheet/telangana-announcement-andhra-pradesh-chief-minister-kiran-kumar-reddy-leaves-for-delhi-398746|title=Telangana announcement: Andhra Pradesh Chief Minister Kiran Kumar Reddy leaves for Delhi|work=NDTV.com}}</ref>
=== Cabinet approval of Telangana state === 3 October 2013, the Union Cabinet approved the creation of the new State of Telangana. A Group of Ministers (GoM) was created to settle issues concerning the new state and the State of Andhra Pradesh.<ref>{{cite web|title=Creation of a new state of Telangana by bifurcating the existing State of Andhra Pradesh|url=http://pib.nic.in/newsite/erelease.aspx?relid=99854|publisher=Home Ministry, Govt. of India|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131004214211/http://pib.nic.in/newsite/erelease.aspx?relid=99854|archivedate=4 October 2013|accessdate=23 December 2014}}</ref> [[Hyderabad, India|Hyderabad]] will be the shared capital for 10 years, after which it will belong to Telangana, said the Home Minister.<ref>{{cite web|title=Telangana state cleared, Hyderabad shared capital; Seemandhra erupts in protest|url=http://www.ndtv.com/article/cheat-sheet/telangana-state-cleared-hyderabad-shared-capital-seemandhra-erupts-in-protest-427407?curl=1380825978|publisher=NDTV|accessdate=3 October 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Text of Cabinet note on Telangana|url=http://epaper.thehansindia.com/PUBLICATIONS/THEHANSINDIA/THI/2013/10/06/ArticleHtmls/Text-of-Cabinet-Note-on-Telangana-06102013007003.shtml?Mode=1|publisher=The Hans India|accessdate=7 October 2013}}</ref>
On 8 October, recently retired director general of police Dinesh Reddy said the Chief minister, Kiran Kumar Reddy pressured him to issue a public statement that the creation of Telangana would lead to intensification of Maoist activities. He also charged that the CM had reprimanded him for seeking additional central forces for containing expected trouble in Seemandhra in the run up to the Congress Working Committee's Telangana resolution at the end of July.<ref>{{cite web|title=Kiran Kumar Reddy wanted to use me to stall Telangana plan: Former Andhra Pradesh DGP V Dinesh Reddy|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Kiran-Kumar-Reddy-wanted-to-use-me-to-stall-Telangana-plan-Former-Andhra-Pradesh-DGP-V-Dinesh-Reddy/articleshow/23749838.cms|publisher=Times of India|accessdate=10 October 2013}}</ref>
== Events leading to the formation of Telangana ==
=== Formation of Group of Ministers (GoM) === Govt of India set up the Group of Ministers (GOM) headed by union home minister [[Sushilkumar Shinde]] to address all the issues that need resolution at the central and state government levels during the formation of Telangana state. GOM met on 11 October for the first time released its terms of reference]] on 16 Oct.<ref>{{cite web|title=Telangana GoM Seeks Feedback on Terms of Reference|url=http://news.outlookindia.com/items.aspx?artid=813753|publisher=Outlook|accessdate=16 October 2013}}</ref> GOM met 2nd time on 19 October and considered the background notes which had been prepared by the Home Ministry regarding the various issues pertaining to the bifurcation. It also asked feedback from public to send their suggestions pertaining to the specific terms of reference before 5 November.<ref>{{cite web|title=Second Meeting of GoM on Telangana Held|url=http://pib.nic.in/newsite/erelease.aspx?relid=100133|publisher=Ministry of Home Affairs|accessdate=30 October 2013}}</ref> On 29 October, the background notes prepared by Home ministry for GOM appeared in the media.<ref>{{cite web|title=BACKGROUND NOTE FOR THE GROUP OF MINISTERS (GoM) REGARDING THE CREATION OF THE STATE OF TELANGANA FROM THE EXISTING STATE OF ANDHRA PRADESH|url=http://www.rediff.com/news/2013/oct/29creation-of-state-of-telangana.pdf|publisher=MINISTRY OF HOME AFFAIRS|accessdate=30 October 2013}}</ref> On 30 October, Union Home Minister Sushil Kumar Shinde called for an all-party meeting, to be attended by representatives of national and regional parties of the state, to discuss the issues related to bifurcation.<ref>{{cite web|title=Telangana: Govt convenes all-party meeting on Andhra Pradesh division|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Telangana-Govt-convenes-all-party-meeting-on-Andhra-Pradesh-division/articleshow/24950258.cms?|publisher=Times of India|accessdate=30 October 2013}}</ref> In a letter to 8 major political parties in the state, home ministry asked the parties to submit their suggestions to the GoM by 5 November, following which an all-party meeting will be held.<ref>{{cite web|title=GoM on Telangana seeks suggestions from parties|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/GoM-on-Telangana-seeks-suggestions-from-parties/articleshow/25017295.cms|publisher=Times of India|accessdate=31 October 2013}}</ref> On 13-14 November GOM met the representatives all parties of the state to discuss (TDP boycotted the meeting) about the issues related to bifurcation.<ref>{{cite web|title=GoM on Telangana meets representatives of political parties|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2013-11-12/india/43979345_1_telangana-rashtra-samithi-gom-seemandhra|publisher=Times of India}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Andhra Pradesh should be kept united: YSR Congress, CPM|url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/politics/andhra-pradesh-should-be-kept-united-ysr-congress-cpm-113111300657_1.html|publisher=Business Standard|accessdate=30 November 2013}}</ref> GOM had meetings including some with CM, Deputy CM, cabinet ministers from the state and other state leaders while finalizing the Telangana draft bill.<ref>{{cite web|title=Group of Ministers finalizes draft Telangana bill|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Group-of-Ministers-finalizes-draft-Telangana-bill/articleshow/26483314.cms|publisher=Times of India|accessdate=30 November 2013}}</ref>
On 3 December, Talk of including two [[Rayalaseema]] districts, [[Ananthapur district]] and [[Kurnool district]], in Telangana state by GOM was criticised by pro-Telangana groups. TRS and JAC called for Telangana wide bandh (strike) on 5 December 2013 which had a good response.<ref>{{cite web|title=TRS' Telangana bandh evokes good response against creation of Rayala-Telangana|url=http://www.financialexpress.com/news/trs-telangana-bandh-evokes-good-response-against-creation-of-rayalatelangana/1203766|publisher=Financial Express|accessdate=5 December 2013}}</ref>
On the evening of 5 December 2013, the cabinet approved the Telangana draft bill prepared by Group of Ministers (GoM). The bill have to approved by Parliament before it becomes 29th state of the union.<ref>{{cite web|title=Cabinet clears bill for creation of Telangana with 10 districts|url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/politics-and-nation/cabinet-clears-bill-for-creation-of-telangana-with-10-districts/articleshow/26918625.cms|publisher=Economic Times|accessdate=5 December 2013}}</ref>
=== Legislative proceedings ===
6 December 2013: India's Union Home Ministry sends the Telangana draft bill to The President of India.<ref>{{cite web|title=Telangana bill sent to president|url=http://www.ndtv.com/article/south/telangana-bill-sent-to-president-455545|publisher=NDTV|accessdate=13 December 2013}}</ref>
11 December 2013: The President of India reviews the bill and passes it on to the Andhra Pradesh State Assembly to elicit its views, giving it until 23 January to respond with its views. The bill was urgently hand-delivered the following day,to Assembly Secretariat by the Joint Secretary of Union Home Ministry.<ref>{{cite web|title=President gives Andhra time till Jan 23 to debate Telangana Bill|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/President-gives-Andhra-time-till-Jan-23-to-debate-Telangana-Bill/articleshow/27253291.cms|publisher=Times of India|accessdate=13 December 2013}}</ref>
16 December 2013: The Telangana draft bill<ref>[http://www.aplegislature.org/en_GB/c/document_library/get_file?uuid=7d75ff22-eb59-4a24-9c03-348d89498ee4&groupId=11343 The Telangana draft bill] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140518043714/http://www.aplegislature.org/en_GB/c/document_library/get_file?uuid=7d75ff22-eb59-4a24-9c03-348d89498ee4&groupId=11343 |date=18 May 2014 }}</ref> was introduced in Andhra Pradesh state assembly by deputy speaker [[Mallu Bhatti Vikramarka]] in the speaker's absence. This was met by protests and chaos created by the Seemandhra MLAs.<ref>{{cite web|title=Telangana bill tabled in Andhra Pradesh Assembly|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/india-news/telanganathetroubledstate/telangana-bill-tabled-in-ap-assembly-amid-din/article1-1163043.aspx|publisher=Hindustan times|accessdate=16 December 2013}}</ref>
17 December 2013: Assembly's proceedings remain disrupted. The Business Advisory Committee (BAC) of the State Assembly decides to discuss the Bill starting the following day.<ref>{{cite web|title=Draft Telangana Bill: Assembly to take up discussion from Wednesday|url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/politics/draft-telangana-bill-assembly-to-take-up-discussion-from-wednesday-113121700848_1.html|publisher=Business Standard|accessdate=17 December 2013}}</ref> This evokes mixed reactions including allegations on Seemandhra leaders' attempt to derail the bill by delaying the process.
18,19 December 2013: Assembly proceedings continue to be disrupted. The situation forces the speaker, [[Nadendla Manohar]] to adjourn the house until 3 January. This is met with protests from the Telangana MLAs.<ref>{{cite web|title=Telangana MLAs protest Speaker's action to adjourn AP assembly|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/telangana-mlas-protest-speaker-action-to-adjourn-ap-assembly/1/331933.html|publisher=India Today|accessdate=19 December 2013}}</ref> Telangana and Seemandhra leaders meet The President [[Pranab Mukherjee]] vying with each other to complain about the way the Telangana bill was being handled.<ref>{{cite web|title=Seemandhra, T Leaders Vie with One Another to Complain to Pranab|url=http://www.newindianexpress.com/states/andhra_pradesh/Seemandhra-T-Leaders-Vie-with-One-Another-to-Complain-to-Pranab/2013/12/23/article1960484.ece|publisher=New Indian Express|accessdate=24 December 2013}}</ref>
1 January 2014: 2 days before the start of the next assembly session, the Chief Minister Kiran kumar Reddy replaces D Sridhar Babu with S Sailajanath. This move comes criticised as the former hails from Telangana and the latter is actively involved with [[Samaikyandhra Movement]]. [[Sridhar Babu]] resigns from the cabinet in protest.<ref>{{cite web|title=Minister from Telangana Sridhar Babu quits after losing key portfolio|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2014-01-02/india/45798344_1_education-minister-n-kiran-kumar-reddy-chief-minister|publisher=Times of India|accessdate=4 January 2014}}</ref>
3,4 January 2014: Situation fails to improve as Assembly sessions remain disrupted.<ref>{{cite web|title=All Eyes on Speaker as Telangana Debate Goes Nowhere|url=http://www.newindianexpress.com/states/andhra_pradesh/All-Eyes-on-Speaker-as-Telangana-Debate-Goes-Nowhere/2014/01/04/article1981872.ece|publisher=New Indian Express|accessdate=4 January 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=AP Assembly adjourned amidst noisy scenes|url=http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/news/states/ap-assembly-adjourned-amidst-noisy-scenes/article5537753.ece|publisher=Hindu Business Line|accessdate=4 January 2014}}</ref>
6 January 2014: Unable to continue Assembly sessions amid chaos, the speaker requests members to submit written amendments, if any, to the clauses of the Bill by 10 January.<ref>{{cite web|title=AP Reorganisation Bill: Speaker asks members to submit written amendments by Jan 10|url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/politics/ap-reorganisation-bill-speaker-asks-members-to-submit-written-amendments-by-jan-10-114010601022_1.html|publisher=Business standard|accessdate=6 January 2014}}</ref>
8 January 2014: The bill is finally taken up for debate. However, this lasts for only a few minutes with the YSR Congress Party MLAs resuming protests.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/news/politics/ap-houses-begin-debate-on-tbill-amid-ruckus/article5554090.ece|title=AP Houses begin debate on T-Bill amid ruckus|publisher=HIndu Business Line|accessdate=9 January 2014}}</ref>
9 January: The debate continues only after YSRCP MLAs were suspended. While there was polarisation on regional lines, debate more or less turned into a blame game over the state bifurcation issue as every party indulged in a game of political one-upmanship. Congress leader from Seemandhra and minister Vatti Vasanth Kumar spoke opposing the Telangana bill and said bifurcation is against Seemandhra interests.<ref>{{cite web|title=Telangana: Debate on draft Bill turns into political slugfest|url=http://www.deccanchronicle.com/140110/news-current-affairs/article/telangana-debate-draft-bill-turns-political-slugfest|publisher=Deccan Chronicle(PTI)|accessdate=10 January 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=T-Bill Debate Generates Heat|url=http://www.newindianexpress.com/states/andhra_pradesh/T-Bill-Debate-Generates-Heat/2014/01/10/article1992452.ece|publisher=New Indian Express|accessdate=10 January 2014}}</ref> On 10 January, debate started after YSRCP members staged walk out. Among others, TRS floor leader, E Rajender spoke in length supporting Telangana bill while highlighting the grievances of Telangana people and the history of the movement. CPI floor leader G Mallesh, Congress leader from Telangana and government chief whip Gandra Venkaramana Reddy spoke supporting Telangana bill. House was adjorned until 17 January.<ref>{{cite web|title=Tempers Run High Again During Debate|url=http://www.newindianexpress.com/states/andhra_pradesh/Tempers-Run-High-Again-During-Debate/2014/01/11/article1994762.ece|publisher=New Indian Express|accessdate=11 January 2014}}</ref> After 17 January, debate had less disruptions. Chief Minister requested the President four weeks of additional time for the debate a move opposed by Telangana leaders.<ref>{{cite web|title=T-leaders oppose extra time, fax plea to President|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/andhra-pradesh/tleaders-oppose-extra-time-fax-plea-to-president/article5598363.ece|publisher=The Hindu|accessdate=24 January 2014}}</ref> On 23 January, President gave 7days extension, until 30 January, for assembly to give its views on Telangana draft bill.<ref>{{cite web|title=President gives 7 days to AP assembly to discuss Telangana Bill|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/President-gives-7-days-to-AP-assembly-to-discuss-Telangana-Bill/articleshow/29248577.cms|publisher=Times of India|accessdate=24 January 2014}}</ref>
23-25 Jan 2014: The Chief Minister presents his analysis on how the bifurcation is detrimental to both regions, the highlights being the effect on current irrigation projects in Telangana and better subsidised electricity given to farmers of Telangana. Telangana MLAs ridicule the Chief Minister and prevent the proceedings citing no opportunity to make a counter argument. The Chief Minister later expresses his opinion as the AP Reorganisation Bill-2013 being defective. Other members view this as an unduly delayed reaction.<ref>{{cite web|title=Division Will Hit All Regions: Kiran Kumar Reddy|url=http://www.newindianexpress.com/states/andhra_pradesh/Division-Will-Hit-All-Regions-Kiran-Kumar-Reddy/2014/01/24/article2017100.ece|publisher=New Indian Express|accessdate=31 January 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Kiran finds holes in T Bill|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2014-01-26/india/46635986_1_draft-bill-kiran-kumar-reddy-original-bill|publisher=Times of India|accessdate=31 January 2014}}</ref>
27 Jan 2014: Chief Minister Kirankumar Reddy, gave notice to assembly speaker requesting to move resolution rejecting the Telangana bill. The move was criticised by Telangana MLAs including the ministers and deputy chief minister saying that cabinet was not consulted on the subject. They said this "''amounts to defying the Union Cabinet, Constitution and President''". After this, no debate was possible in the assembly as Telangana members insisted that speaker reject the Chief minister's notice.<ref>{{cite web|title=Stalemate continues over Telangana bill in Andhra legislature|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/india/report-stalemate-continues-over-telangana-bill-in-andhra-legislature-1957953|publisher=DNA India|accessdate=31 January 2014}}</ref>
On 30 January 2014, Andhra Pradesh assembly speaker declared that assembly completed the debate and all the members gave their views. He said, he would send to the President of India a compilation of 9,072 suggestions and amendments he received in writing from members, including 87 members who had spoken on the Bill in the house. Further he accepted the Chief minister's notice of resolution to reject the AP Reorganisation Bill and declared that resolution passed by voice vote without even waiting for the MLAs in the house to say ‘aye’, admist pandemonium and protests from Telangana MLAs. Earlier in the day Seemandhra members rushed to the well of the House demanding that the resolution moved by the CM, without cabinet approval, be put to vote, those from the Telangana region, including the ministers and deputy chief minister, did the same with the demand that there should be no voting. At 11.30 pm, in what appears to be a coordinated strategy between the speaker, the chief minister and the Seemandhra legislators, all the members from that region converged at the well of the House and formed a wall around the speaker even as Manohar read out the resolution, put it to voice vote and declared it as having been passed. The bill will now be sent back to President Pranab Mukherjee after which it is slated to be tabled in Parliament.<ref name="ap res">{{cite news|last=Lakshman|first=Ganesh|title=Andhra Pradesh assembly rejects Telangana Bill|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Andhra-Pradesh-assembly-rejects-Telangana-Bill/articleshow/29594366.cms|accessdate=30 Jan 2014|newspaper=Times of India|date=30 Jan 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=AP Assembly rejects Telangana Bill, final say with Parliament|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/india/politics/ap-assembly-rejects-telangana-bill-final-say-with-parliament/|publisher=Indian Express|accessdate=31 January 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Seemandhra leaders’ strategy takes T-counterparts by surprise|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/andhra-pradesh/seemandhra-leaders-strategy-takes-tcounterparts-by-surprise/article5638041.ece|publisher=The Hindu|accessdate=31 January 2014}}</ref> The resolution was placed in the house and was declared passed within 15 seconds.<ref>{{cite web|title=AP assembly approves cm's resolution to oppose the bill(video)|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Nv7XwzVWWCc|publisher=V6 News|accessdate=1 February 2014}}</ref> Analysts say "rejection of Telangana bill" is not valid and is useful only for political grand standing.<ref>{{cite web|title=How Valid Is the Chief Minister's Resolution Adopted by Voice Vote ?|url=http://www.newindianexpress.com/states/andhra_pradesh/How-Valid-Is-the-Chief-Ministers-Resolution-Adopted-by-Voice-Vote-/2014/01/31/article2029490.ece|publisher=New Indian Express|accessdate=31 January 2014}}</ref> Union cabinet minister Jaipal Reddy said that the resolution to reject the Telangana bill was passed in the assembly by cheating and it has no statutory and political sanctity.<ref>{{cite web|title=Telangana State soon: Jaipal|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/andhra-pradesh/telangana-state-soon-jaipal/article5640660.ece|publisher=The Hindu|accessdate=1 February 2014}}</ref> General secretary of Congress Party and party's in-charge for Andhra Pradesh, Digvijay Singh said that the bill that the President sent to the Assembly was never meant to be put to vote and said that the Congress high command and the Center would go ahead with its plans to introduce and pass the Telangana Bill in Parliament during the forthcoming session.<ref>{{cite web|title=Hopeful of opposition support on Telangana Bill: Congress|url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/politics-and-nation/hopeful-of-opposition-support-on-telangana-bill-congress/articleshow/29635081.cms|publisher=Economic Times|accessdate=31 January 2014}}</ref>
On 4 February, GOM cleared the Telangana bill after making few amendments to it based upon the input from state assembly.<ref>{{cite web|title=GoM clears Telangana Bill, suggests changes|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/GoM-clears-Telangana-Bill-suggests-changes/articleshow/29872046.cms|publisher=Times of India|accessdate=4 February 2014}}</ref>
On 7 February, Union cabinet cleared the Telangana bill and plans to introduce in upper house of Parliament with 32 amendments. Amendments include the details of financial package to Seemandhra to address their concerns.<ref>{{cite web|title=Telangana bill to face RS test on February 12, cabinet says no to UT status for Hyderabad|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/india-news/union-cabinet-clears-telangana-bill-hyderabad-to-be-joint-capital/article1-1181657.aspx|publisher=Hindustan Times|accessdate=7 February 2014}}</ref>
On 13 February, Telangana bill was introduced in the [[Lok Sabha]], the lower house of Parliament, by Union home minister, [[Sushilkumar Shinde]] despite protests, disruptions of Seemandhra MPs. In an unprecedented incidence, the use of pepper spray by Seemandhra MP, [[Lagadapati Rajagopal]] in the Lok Sabha during the introduction of the bill caused all the members to leave the house and some members to be hospitalised.<ref>{{cite web|title=Telangana bill: Pepper spray in Parliament leaves Indian democracy in tears|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Telangana-bill-Pepper-spray-in-Parliament-leaves-Indian-democracy-in-tears/articleshow/30358994.cms|publisher=Times of India|accessdate=14 February 2014}}</ref>
18 February 2014: the Telangana Bill is passed by the [[Lok Sabha]] with support from the Congress, TRS and other local parties.<ref>{{cite web|title=Telangana bill passed in Lok Sabha; Congress, BJP come together in favour of new state|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/india-news/telanganathetroubledstate/parliament-adjourned-till-noon-over-telangana-issue/article1-1185194.aspx|publisher=Hindustan Times|accessdate=18 February 2014}}</ref> Broadcast of the proceedings enters a blackout during the voice vote. This caused widespread criticism of the manner in which the bill was passed.<ref name="Loksabha Blackout">{{cite web | url=http://www.firstpost.com/politics/blacking-out-lok-sabha-tv-for-telangana-did-the-end-justify-the-means-1397221.html | title=Loksabha Blackout | publisher=First Post | accessdate=June 19, 2014}}</ref>
20 February 2014: The Telangana bill is passed by [[Rajya Sabha]] with the support from the Congress, TRS, BJP and other local parties.<ref>{{cite web|title=Rajya Sabha passes Telangana bill|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/india-news/telanganathetroubledstate/rajya-sabha-passes-telangana-bill/article1-1186266.aspx|publisher=Hindustan Times|accessdate=20 February 2014}}</ref> The bill receives the assent of the President and published in the gazette on 1 March 2014.<ref>{{cite web|title=THE ANDHRA PRADESH REORGANISATION ACT, 2014|url=http://www.mha.nic.in/sites/upload_files/mha/files/APRegACT2014_0.pdf|publisher=Ministry of Law and Justice, Government of India|accessdate=3 March 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160108223043/http://www.mha.nic.in/sites/upload_files/mha/files/APRegACT2014_0.pdf|archivedate=8 January 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref> On 4 March 2014 the Government of India declares 2 June 2014 the [[Telangana Formation Day]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Notification|url=http://www.egazette.nic.in/WriteReadData/2014/158365.pdf|work=The Gazette of India|publisher=Government of India|accessdate=4 March 2014|format=PDF|date=4 March 2014}}</ref> Telangana is the 29th state of the Union of India with Hyderabad as its capital. Both states will share the capital for 10 years until Seemandhra can establish its own. However, the revenues of Hyderabad and state governing power will go only to Telangana. No special status was accorded to Seemandhra, though it was hinted in the Telangana Bill.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/no-special-category-status-for-seemandhra-plan-panel/article6111403.ece|title=No special category status for Seemandhra: plan panel|author=PTI|work=The Hindu}}</ref>
